intro: Relbunium hirtum var. camporum, commonly known as the Camp's hairy bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Europe. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and thrives in alpine or subalpine environments. Its flowers are tubular with five lobes and are often visited by pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Relbunium hirtum var. camporum is relatively rare and is of interest to botanists due to its limited distribution and unique ecological adaptations.
